article.title: Measuring growth index in a universe with massive neutrinos: A revisit of the general relativity test with the latest observations

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 1, what does the grey dotted line in the top panel represent?
choices: The constraint on γ from RSD data only.
The best-fit value of γ for the ACDM+y model.
The theoretical prediction of γ according to General Relativity.
The constraint on γ from Planck TT,TE,EE data only.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 1, what is the effect of considering massive sterile neutrinos (ACDM+y+m_sterile+N_eff model) on the constraint of Ωm compared to the base ACDM+y model?
choices: The constraint on Ωm becomes significantly tighter.
The constraint on Ωm remains almost the same.
The best-fit value of Ωm is lowered, and its uncertainty increases.
The best-fit value of Ωm is increased, and its uncertainty increases.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded about the constraint on γ from Figure 2 when comparing the models with and without massive active neutrinos (different hierarchies)?
choices: The inclusion of massive neutrinos significantly tightens the constraint on γ.
The constraint on γ is highly dependent on the assumed neutrino mass hierarchy.
The constraint on γ remains largely unaffected by the inclusion of massive neutrinos.
The inclusion of massive neutrinos completely removes the tension between the measured γ and the GR prediction.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to Figure 2, what happens to the constraint on  Ωm when massive active neutrinos are included in the model compared to the base ACDM+y model?
choices: The constraint on Ωm remains completely unchanged.
The best-fit value of Ωm decreases, and its uncertainty decreases.
The constraint on Ωm becomes significantly tighter.
The best-fit value of Ωm increases, and its uncertainty increases.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to Table IV, what is the upper limit on the sum of neutrino masses (Σmν) for the ACDM+y+Σmν (IH) model?
choices: Σmν < 0.374 eV
Σmν < 0.390 eV
Σmν < 0.406 eV
Σmν < 0.668 eV
